Topic.Title: IPhone 5

Message.Msg: The bigger issue will be the release of next Gen iPads with Siri. Just as Siri had a big impact on the phone space, so too will it on the tablet space, especially smaller form factor tablets where typing is more difficult. People will happily pay up for a Siri enabled 7" iPad over the Kindle Fire. And now that DOJ has cleared the way for Apple to attack Kindle books on price, Amazon will feel some real pain as it continues to invest while getting squeezed on cash flow.

Topic.Title: Capital World, T Row Price, Vangard, Fidelity (FMR), and Capital Research

Message.Msg: I don't think people fully understand the scam. Machines trading back and forth, facilitated by GS, and pingponging between TROW, CAP, FMR, and the others. Its a big ponzi scheme coupled with a giant game of chicken. But as long as the FED keeps fueling the scam with free money, what makes it crack?

Topic.Title: Capital World, T Row Price, Vangard, Fidelity (FMR), and Capital Research

Message.Msg: What makes it crack is a robot blinks.... Why would a robot blink, You ask? Because a bot owner programz it to blink.... What makes a robot blink, you querry? Almost anything: a market top, the robot has had enough and is down for maintenance, it thought it saw another robot blink, bernanke prints one dollar too little, the london whale, and one phat phingered trade (a joke of an excuse).... Yep, you cant ask when a robot will blink, or what will make it do so you just have to know that it will, and trade responsibly with that knowledge.... You also have to hope that when a robot blinks that the marjets continue to function afterward so that you can make your trade... Funny things happen when robots blink, and if the markets dont funcrion properly as a result then BOTH sides of the trade are fvcked: The "buy to cover" cant buy, and the panik "sell" cant sell, yet life would still go on, amazingly enough (think weekends, nights and holidayz here). This brings sybil full circle to the premise that scam stok markets are comprised of stox denominated in worthless digital credits who's only dollar value is what the knucklehead or robot on the other end of the wire will pay for them during market hours and when the market is functioning properly... The stok markets sole purpose has been retasked over the last 30 years from a reasonable way to raise equity capital to fund a really good idea to be a wealth stripping machine whose primary function is to tranfer wealth from the many and redistribute it to the few as efficiently as possible.... The end. Amen.

Message.Title: Amazon Going Higher!!
Message.Msg: Amazon is going to blow through their Kindles. Outside of the Iphone which I don't care for. Apple will only probably sell the Nano. Anyone in their right mind is not going to buy a 4 inch Ipod touch for $299 or $399 when you can get a larger screen Kindle. The sweet spot is the $199 market! As for the Sales Tax in Cali. people will still order. I live in New York, and i said the same thing. Guess what, I'm still using amazon more then ever. It's about convenience / service. Think about it. I'm going to spend my money where i get the best service and by far amazon rocks!

Message.Title: IPod
Message.Msg: Buried in the iPhone 5 announcement was a new line of iPods, including a $300 iPod touch with Siri and high definition camera. Also new ear pods. Why would someone want a $300 4 inch iPod when they could buy a 7 inch Kindle Fire for half the price? One word: Games. Side note. I'am very surprised Amazon did not announce a TV set top box. The Apple TV will dominate video streaming and will never support Amazon Prime. I also have a Roku which does support AP. But in almost every other way, the Apple is superior. The only thing Apple lacks is support for non-HDMI TVs, but as people buy new TVs, this advantage goes away. The closed captions on Apple are much clearer than Roku. The remote control can be programmed to use the original remote that came with the TV.

Topic.Title: Amazon Going Higher!!

Message.Msg: Mr: I agree with you that people will buy on Amazon even with sales tax. I have purchased more from Amazon this year than last and been more satisfied. I have also decided to switch from paper books to electronic. But a recession is coming and that means people will be buying fewer discretionary goods. I don't know where the top is, but I can't see the bull market lasting past December. Meanwhile many 3rd and 2nd tier stocks are already in bear markets.

Message.Title: Why does Mossberg's Review Even Matter?
Message.Msg: "What are all the services that have such tremendous value and are not available on the iPad or Android platform? C'mon man. Color me a skeptic, but I don't think X-Ray moves the needle..." Well, they're services based on customer requests so I guess they move the needle a lot with the people who really count. Mossberg and shorts' negative views about Kindles have never done much good for shorts in the past. Don't count on this trend changing. “Mossberg reviews Amazon’s Kindle: ‘clumsy and poorly designed’” Thursday, November 29, 2007 - 4:04 pm Amazon share price: Nov 29, 2007: $90 Today : $254 I think that about says it all.

Message.Msg: "I'am very surprised Amazon did not announce a TV set top box. The Apple TV will dominate video streaming and will never support Amazon Prime." Didn't they have to postpone their launch for another 12 months?

Topic.Title: Sound like the HD FIRE sucks.

Message.Msg: All the reviewers said it is inferior to the Nexus 7. Why pay $214 for Fire HD when the current gold standard Nexus 7 is only $199. I've seen N7 sold for $20 less at Staples due to promo/discount. There's also a software update that will allow N7 to record at 720p resolution.

Topic.Title: IPod

Message.Msg: Amazon's biggest weakness (other than sales tax now), is their online movies. I used to love the movies on the site, and the $1.00 movie deals, but while you may get HD movie rentals(too expensive especially for the older movies), none of the purchases are HD, and even then, not good quality and shaky connection....imo. And lately not any good one buck movies. I have recently switched to all iTunes movies all the time, either rent some or buy the ones I like. That way, I have them all together on iTunes and the quality never decreases and I can depend on Apple to have them and move them to other devices very easily. Now even Apple has discounts on some rentals and buys too. I am very surprised that so many love Amazon stock here. I like buying alot on the site, but I always check other sites, and I have even made some better/cheaper cost buys on high end things on Ebay, with great satisfaction.

Topic.Title: Why does Mossberg's Review Even Matter?

Message.Msg: Let's see. I tell you all the features, you say "they don't move needle", Amazon sells zillions of Fires anyway, the stock goes up way higher than the breaking point on your $230 short, you go home broke crying to your Mommy about how unfair the markets have become to you. Now, does this story change at all if we leave out the part where I tell you about all the services (which you keep trying to "play dumb" about not knowing)? No, it doesn't.

Message.Msg: "According to a report released by Forrester Research in late July, about 30% of shoppers at least started their last online purchase by searching on Amazon, compared with 13% who turned first to Google. Only three years before, just 18% started their searches on Amazon, while nearly 25% used Google first." But I thought techstrategy who is long on Google told me that Google had shopping search all wrapped up? He must not have been reading any of the Forrester Research reports since 2009 I guess.

Topic.Title: IPod

Message.Msg: nemesis: Thanks for pointing out that the Fire has an HDMI connection. Not a great solution, but I did forget. The Apple TV is currently a $99 module that is continuously being (software) upgraded. Apple is working on other set top box ideas, but most of the rumors have proven untrue. BTW: I got stopped out of my short today. AMZN is going higher. My bad. I really didn't think the Fed would announce QE3 right before an election. Bernake is dead meat.

Topic.Title: 260 very critical in the next 57 minutes.

Message.Msg: Actually, I said the Google was taking Shopping seriously and now was focused squarely on competing with Amazon. The recent decision to charge for listings in Google Shopping is consistent with that thrust. Google is upgrading the quality of the the Shopping results / content. "Google Shopping has one attractive feature that Amazon lacks: a button labeled "In Stock Nearby," which filters results for matching products in and around the user's zip code. That's a great feature for Google local advertisers, and Amazon is unlikely to add it." Google is about to compete by enabling consumers to access products at the best prices proximate to the consumer -- delivering value to the consumer without taking on excessive and redundant low value added low ROIC warehousing and distribution infrastructure. If you remember what I said it was that Google would enable existing retailers to better service consumers without adopting Amazon's ridiculously capital intensive (malinvestment) approach. Google will ultimately end up leapfrogging Amazon because Amazon is still in the business of competing with mainstream brick and mortar retailers... Amazon is burning more cash all the time. Lots of new TV ads = more overhead...

Topic.Title: IPod

Message.Msg: Edison: Honestly, I didn't think Ben would be stupid enough to do it. A false sense of security is dangerous. Now, when something goes wrong the crisis of confidence will be much worse if not irreparable. But, it is also why I have been short mainly consumer/retail stories. The commodity/oil/gas inflation will hit the consumer hard and negate the Fed's money printing. Take Amazon. Shipping costs will go up. Even with Amazon's investment in more local warehousing, fuel costs will hit Amazon harder than traditional bricks and mortar retail because consumers simply do not calculate the fuel costs of driving to the store. Amazon, pays for the "last mile". Gas price increases favor Costco, WalMart and Target which service a broad array of consumer needs. Money printing hurts Amazon's competitive and strategic position...
